Lagonda is a British luxury car brand established in 1906, which has been owned by Aston Martin since 1947. The trade-name has not had a continuous commercial existence, being dormant several times, most recently from 1995 to 2008 and 2010 to 2013.

After reading the comments, i'm surprised people are trying to justify or disprove the million dollar tag price. There's no substitute for scarcity. Having lived a few years in Dubai, the one thing they squander money on are licence plates, a few of those costing more than a million dollars : for a license PLATE. A piece of square, cheap tin with a couple of numbers written. Uniqueness is worth a lot in UAE/KSA/KWT/BHR/QAT. Once you've seen a dozen Veyron, a thousand RR, a million Benz/Maybach, you realise : A Taraf separates true posh from wannabes.

I think they could have designed a better light bar specifically for this car that would have complimented the design a bit better. It's a nice looking car, but I think after the novelty wears off the car will still be beautiful, but perhaps not the most beautiful sedan ever made.

Ya, expensive cars are a joke. It's not even the car, it's the person. You can have a pink car, that's comfy and works well, but people will care more about you than the car. The boomers and previous generation buying into deceptive loans and cars, continuing into today with people who buy expensive branding is only going to lead to waste and over-expense.. Even cars that most older guys seem to think 'make you jealous' like the tinged low sport cars tend to be cringey. Many guys buy those cars after being tricked thinking 'wow, what a sport car, it's my dream', but you honestly look cringey and dumb inside of it and it also tends to look out of place in normal driving. What you typically want is a good deal on a used or cheap car that's like-new, you can find sometimes convertibles and custom work if you want, and/or look for good MPG on any car that gives you luxury or storage if that's your intent. If you want more MPG and storage room, or specific use cases, there's cars for that. You can literally devise cheap solutions that save you 'thousands' because that's how much hype is in the industry. If you know what you're doing and you want things like TVs on the back of the car, like if you really wanted that, you can probably hook it all up for like 20$ + the cost of each TV screen, it'd probably add up to be <100$ for cheaply hooking up 2 small screens to a DVD player or like some satellite TV that would be good for a car for example; and generally you'd only want one screen, plus no one wants tiny screens so they're cheap. You can hook 'into' the electrical system on any part, 'or' even easier convert the existing cigar/power port and plug in an adapter that can easily handle the screen and video input device, just make sure your battery has good amp and capacity and such; and consider overall greenness and power-draw of everything you use to ensure years of usage; if you even keep it all plugged in all the time. Luxury is only a brand. I can't imagine spending anything over 10k on a car really, unless you're just rich, and want to waste. You can even emulate some things like the coating and color of the car, and sometimes a few customizations or rarities that make a difference between a cheap car and a car that looks and runs good. They price like 10$ solutions at like 1000$+ it's ridiculous crap. What is the outside of this car, black plastic? Looks ok but it's not really my idea of cool.

C'mon Doug, quit using the term "hand stitched".  Auto makers, at least the ones interested in profit, do not employ people with needles and thread stitching by hand items like seats, dashboards, door panels, headliners etc.  The stitching is done by a commercial sewing machine.  The correct term is "machine stitched".  The operator obviously has acquired a good amount of skill to place those stitches exactly where they are supposed to go.  He or she does use that skill and hand-eye coordination to get the job done.  As for the car itself, it's a pretty nice $150,000.00 car.  If you pay a million bucks for this maintenance nightmare waiting to happen, you're nuts.

Ok, I'll say it:  This car looks like crap.  Everything about the exterior looks sort of but not quite like something else.  The grill reminds me of a Ford.  The rear end looks like a cross between a Chevy and a Tesla.  The side "lines" are reminiscent of a cross between a Tesla and a Dodge.  The door handle concept is straight out of a Tesla - the cheapest Tesla, the Model 3, not the cool handles from the S.  And all that brown leather on the interior looks like shit - literally, I've had poops that exact color.  The gauges and buttons in this 2018 look like they'd be right at home in 1998.  Throw in Aston's famous reliability and this thing is the opposite of luxury. Given how completely cool the tech in the last Lagonda Doug reviewed was, this turd is a sad joke.  A million dollars is insane, this is maybe a $150k car (and that's me being generous because of the top speed, it would be worth maybe $40k otherwise) with an extra $15k of seriously fugly leatherwork.  No, I'm not joking about the leather cost, you could probably get that done to your car for about $15k, you just wouldn't want to because it's fugly. Also, LOL at Doug gushing about the turn signals.  Yeah, dual color LEDs are under $10 each in low quantities.  Such "luxury".

That the door handles have the same colour as the body rather than chrome is a good feature. But that one can see the 'intestines' of the brakes with those red brake shoes that look like guts filled with blood, is an unaesthetic item. My old Mercedes 190E (Type 201) possesses much nicer wheel rims that discreetly cover up such mechanical 'intestines'.  One other drawback are the rear-view mirros at 4:6 which stick out of the cicumference  of the car body  and into the air, like too big ears protruding out of a head. They look a bit 'forlorn'. At my Mercedes they are 'integrated' at the triangle formed at the end of the side window and the front door. A million-dollar car and Mr. DeMuro is still wearing those childisch looking short pants that really are not congruent to what he is talkig about. The turn signals is much too small to be seen, especially in sunny California. Well, you can lower the front window and give turn signals by sticking out your arm (for left turns) and raising up your arm up in the air (for right turns) which is the way to do it in Californa. Loganda Taraf - what a funny name and what a terrible car at 8:03. I still prefer the name Aston Martin. Just as I prefer the name Mercedes instead of Maybach. Ultimate luxury in Arabic means    Ù„ÙØ®Ø§Ù…Ø© Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø·Ù„Ù‚Ø©   whereas 'Taraf' means a group of people of a certain allegiance or adherence, with which Aston Martin presumably means its customers for this car. Ten times more expensive than a Rapide?!?  Veblen effect - Abnormal market behavior where consumers purchase the higher-priced goods whereas similar low-priced (but not identical) substitutes are available. It is caused either by the belief that higher price means higher quality, or by the desire for conspicuous consumption (to be seen as buying an expensive, prestige item). Named after its discoverer, the US social-critic Thorstein Bunde Veblen (1857-1929).
It looks like a future car for a sci-fi movie made in 1991.

"You'd think with an old single-clutch transmission like this..." No, it's not a single clutch unit, it's an 8-speed ZF automatic transmission. Only the V8 and V12 Vantage had the Graziano single clutch automated manuals. In a DB9 (Virage, DBS) or Rapide, the automatic option really is a full-fledged torque converter automatic.

I love the using of ford parts.  My favorite: My brother in law came out to the farm one weekend in his Lincoln Continental. He broke down on our rough driveway. Inspection found the distributor cap had come lose and the rotor was broken. Needing a part on a Sunday, I decided to check my '66 Mustang. Same rotor, My BIL was insistent that it must be a 'similar' part as his car was a Lincoln, not a Ford.  The next day, I was stuck out on the farm with a missing rotor. With nothing better to do, I checked the distributor on the 3 cylinder Ford tractor. You guessed it, the same rotor and I was back on the road. I never told my brother-in-law.

Fun fact: I used to work in the factory manufacturing those seat belt buckles covered in leather. Well, those are just Ford buckles and the majority of them were actually production line rejects which had scratches or other defects, but when covered in leather, those defects were no longer an issue.

The car is nice but it can't be the most beautiful.  Not in that color (subjectively). Not with that keyholes on the doors. Not with that plastic bars separating the fixed and the moving windows on the doors. Not with asymetric brake rotors slots. (Right ones slots face forward and left ones slots face backwards). Not with that massive AIRBAG plaque on the doors. Not full of Ford Focus parts.  The million dollar price tag is entirely for the exclusivity but given that price they could've make an effort in resolving many small deatils and make it truly beautiful.  It's a shame, the car isn't the best executed, nor the most luxurious (S-Class, Flying Spur or Phantom are much better at providing luxury), neither the best performer (although it isn't the purpose)... The design... meh. The windshield looks too much tilted to me and it gets worse compared to the back window tilt,  that C pillars are hideous, the front looks like if a Ford Mondeo and a Honda had a baby...  Also how can the charge $1.000.000 and not giving you an electric trunk door mechanism...  The car is elegant as any Aston Martin but it's just for making easy money from the rich middle east people that will buy it for its exclusivity over anything and it clearly shows.

The Lagonda name does come from a company that Aston bought the late 40â€™s. That company was started by an American guy named Wilbur Gunn, who was an Opera singer living in the UK. The name Lagonda comes from the street he lived on in Springfield, Ohio. The street was named after the Shawnee Native-American settlement, which they called â€˜Lagondaâ€™.

Completely agree that this car isn't worth anything like $1 million, but lots of older cars which are rare are now worth loads but on paper, they are out performed by a hot BMW today. Aston basically manufactured value by building very few, same as supercar companies regularly do (add a little bit of performance and carbon fibre, tweak the styling, quadruple the price, or things like the reventon which is just a murcielago with a body kit). And, they got away with it, because keeping up with the jones' is what's its about at that level, it's not about having the best car, but by having an expensive car you show you have more money than those with a phantom (which you also have already). It's a shame Aston didn't make more effort to set this apart, as having the unique styling would have made this something really special, but it's turned into a rebody of a rapide basically.

The gauge cluster should be a full LCD, the infotainment system should be Mercedes's COMAND system, the center console should have aluminum or piano black instead of stupid plastic, and the rear center console should just be more bespoke and special. Anyone who paid 1 million dollars for this is frankly an idiot. A Rolls Royce would have been a much MUCH better vehicle.

Lagonda is to Aston Martin as Maybach is to Mercedes. David Brown (DB) bought the Lagonda company in 1947 in order to acquire their 2.6 litre engines, which were used in Aston Martins during the 50s. The name has since been revived from time to time for special production vehicles. The Rapide name began with Lagonda in the 1930s and was resurrected in 1961 during the DB era as the limited edition Lagonda Rapide, a 4 door version of the Aston DB4

9:50 The ability to hold or "check" the door in any position is not provided by the gas-assist strut that you point out. Multimatic Inc. (Cdn) developed the "infinite checker" quite some years ago. It's available on several higher end OEM platforms.     The "curb-rise" geometry on these doors is (beautifully) exaggerated to the point of "Swan-wing" doors. In order to make the door "weightless" to the operator throughout the lift swing, the gas-assist strut is added. The porting in the strut will be tuned specifically to that panel such that opening and closing it take the same effort.

When American car maker Wilbur Gunn started making cars in Staines on the far western extremity of London (near to Runnymede, where the barons forced King John to sign the Magna Carta, fact fans) in 1903, he took the Native American name for smooth-running stream, la ohonda, and anglicised it to Lagonda for his range of ultra high end sporting chariots.
Whoever buys this than a Bentley or RR is nuts. This car is only marginally luxurious because the interior is covered in leather. The details sucks.
For 1 Million dollars, i do not want my car to look like a Honda Accord on steroids. This Lagonda is nowhere near as distinctive and eye-catching as a Rolls Royce. Even the Genesis G90 and Jaguar XJ can make a bigger statement on the street. The interior is bland and not memorable at all. Too much leather of the same color. The dashboard is not exciting or modern. It just seems copy-pasted from another Aston. And that umbrella thrown casually in the trunk? Such an afterthough. It almost feels like Aston remembered at the last second that they're building a car to compete with the Rolls. Not to mention the exposed fridge vent in the back. Complete lack of attention to detail.   To conclude, the car lacks distinctiveness. It lacks individuality and presence. It does not scream "Expensive" like a Rolls or a Bentley do. If i see this on the street, i would not immediately know it is a 1 Million Dollar car. The further you look into it, the more it dissapoints.     But, congratulaions to the fine folk who own one of these. I would not say your money is wisely spent, but, you definitely have something to brag over at the dinner party.

You people look so dull to me. You think the price of a car (or any object) only depends on features you get. You can only see your own point of view. It depends on how much it costs to develop and produce. And making few cars means splitting development costs among few buyers. This has custom coach-building (extremely expensive), leather (also) and probably hundreds of tiny custom parts. ...and people who really wanted this and have the money will pay that price because this is rare and beautiful and desirable. I wouldn't be surprised if Aston would have lost money if they sold this for $900K.

The little holes pattern on the seat's upholstery are called "perfings", and together are called "brogue" or "brogueing"; those are terms from the shoemaking world, btw. This is the classic type or brogueing you commonly find in brogue styled shoes. An adornment that was most likely born in northern Britain a few centuries ago and was made popular in North America in the mid 20th c. due to gunboat longwing style shoes, which featured prominent perfing all over. This, of course, does not help to justify the $1M price tag. Then again, most of that money does not reflect on materials/engineering, but on the status owning this car provides, just as Doug suggested, only that more subtledly.

If you were to die today are you 100% sure that you can go to heaven? First, we have to realize that we all have sinned against God who is Holy, so He canâ€™t let one sin in heaven, so He punishes sin with eternal hell. (Revelation 20:15  And whosoever was not found written in the book of life was cast into the lake of fire / Romans 3:23  For all have sinned, and come short of the glory of God). One sin is enough to make us  sinners as one crime is enough to make us  murderers, so we all have to realize that we are  sinners who deserve hell. The good news is that there is a solution to escape hell and that is Jesus Christ and what He did so we can go to heaven. (John 3:16  For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have everlasting life.) (1 Corinthians 15:3-4 For I delivered unto you first of all that which I also received, how that Christ died for our sins according to the scriptures; And that he was buried, and that he rose again the third day according to the scriptures) (Ephesians 2:8-9 For by grace are ye saved through faith; and that not of yourselves: it is the gift of God:9 Not of works, lest any man should boast.) (Romans 3:24-26 Being justified freely by his grace through the redemption that is in Christ Jesus; Whom God hath set forth to be a propitiation through faith in his blood, to declare his righteousness for the remission of sins that are past, through the forbearance of God; To declare, I say, at this time his righteousness: that he might be just, and the justifier of him which believeth in Jesus..). So to get saved by Jesus Christ you have to believe from the heart ONLY on Jesus shed blood at the cross for the cleansing of sins, on His death for all your sins(past, present, future), burial and resurrection the third day, in Him as your personal saviour. You have to TRUST, that His sacrifice, His blood is sufficient to save you. A lot of people think that to get to heaven you have to not sin, do good works, get baptized, go to church, be catholic, etc but this is what God has to say about our works (Isaiah 64:6 But we are all as an unclean thing, and all our righteousnesses are as filthy rags; and we all do fade as a leaf; and our iniquities, like the wind, have taken us away). If the salvation is by our works then why did Jesus had to die on the cross? It is clear that salvation is only by trusting on Jesus Christ, on His sacrifice, His blood.
